the level design means that different levels require totally different strategies. One level may require you to build the tallest tower you can while another may require you to build a small mobile structure while avoiding saws or fire. Another may have you selectively sacrifice some of your goo. This combination of different elements and challenges means that the game never once gets stale or boring. reviewText:
Where to start with this...
I originally played this on a Powermac G5 when it first came out around the end of 2008, I remember that I originally got it sometime around the 2008 election. My attention was focused on this game the whole time.

It's one of those games where it seems extremely simple at first, but then the complexities and depth of it gradually shine through. The puzzles are neat, and I never had to use any skips until the last part (and I normally sucka t puzzles) but they don't feel easy, they feel satisfying regardless.

The visuals are nice, and they're crisp and good looking, and most importantly they do NOT resort to trying to look like pixel art. However, the game does run at a low resolution and there is no way to change it.

The soundtrack... Well, let's just say it's one of the best soundtracks in an Indie game ever produced. It is well performed, it is entirely originally composed, and it doesn't resort to sounding like chiptune or 16-bit stuff to try and manipulate nostalgic nerves. One of the best parts of the game for certain, and even better is that all of the soundtrack (the full versions, not the shortened versions in the game) can be found right on Youtube. Very memorable soundtrack, I can say that about very very few games.

Buy it? YES! It's on sale frequently anyways.

World of Goo (Originally developed in 2008 for the Nintendo Wii) came out in 2009  for the PC by small indie developer 2D Boy, and it's one of the games that started the indie game craze of the 2010s.

Great music, it's catchy and always fits the mood of the puzzle you're on.

Wack story, I honestly can't tell if this game is trying to send me a message about how evil corporations are, or that finding any source of energy won't matter if big business is still around. Either way telling the story through painted signs is kind of dumb. I think a narrator would have fit the game better.

World of Goo is a short and sweet little game that is hard to dislike.

The well balanced physics-based puzzles are thoughtful and intuitive, making you feel rather smart for solving them without ever getting too frustrating or difficult.

The level design complements the art design and always varies, so while the basic mechanics remain the same, World of Goo manages to feel extremely fresh thoughout, never retreading old ground.

The mouse controls can be finnicky sometimes, but this will only frustrate the hardcore players attempting to 100% the achievements by completing all of the OCD variants.

That's my one major complaint with the game: a casual run-through is kept rather easy, while the OCD objectives (time limits, number of goo balls, number of moves, etc.) are very tough, and can be screwed up with tiny control mistakes or physics misjudgements. If you can ignore these optional objectives though, however enticing, you will find a game that remains very enjoyable, albeit somewhat easy, the entire way through.

___/World Of Goo\___
Drag and drop a variety of squeaking, sticky goo-balls to fabricate structures than can be complex, magnificent or grotesque to get your goo-balls across endless chasms, spiky sawblades and slimy pools and into the end-point of each level, a collection tube that satisfyingly hoovers up your goo-balls and spits out your score based on the volume of adorable slimy spheres you have saved.

>Well-crafted challenges, many unique mechanics are thrown at you in the latter stages. Doesn't get frustating.

++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

reviewText:
A Good puzzle type game involving structure creation.

Tl;dr:buy it on sale if you like this type of stuff and don't mind lack of options menu.

Short Review:Pros:
*Interesting and various puzzles, which require planning, timing and (sometimes) speed.
*Ability to skip levels (limited, but can be increased by completing levels).
*Artstyle's great.
*Different environments and types of Goo.
*Sountrack is beautiful and fits perfectly.
*Writing is witty.
*Simple, but enjoyable story.

Cons:
*Options menu? lol, nope. There are no resolution options, no different sound sliders, no ability to disable level cutscenes (yes they are short, but become slightly irritating after a while).
*Menu look ok (it is just icons), but it is not functional and lacks in features: options menu, credits.
*No user created content.
*Sandbox is pretty limited (one (basic) type of Goo).

Other notes:
*Lack of basic game elements (options menu, sandbox and user creativity limitations) really disappointed me.
*Do I recommend buying this on full price? Yes, if you have enough income and interest in this type of games.
*Do I recommend buying this on sale? Yes, of course (if you like puzzle games ;-) ).

reviewText:
It's a fun game. It's got a lot of puzzle variety and a pretty good amount of content. But it's so bare bones in certain areas that I was absolutely convinced it was a poorly done mobile port until somebody corrected me.

What am I talking about? Dispite being a PC game first, it has no options menu of any kind, you can't correct the resolution, change the graphics (though I doubt you would need to) or even do something as simple as change the game volume. Distinguishing between the balls must be hell if you're colorblind, a menu option for that would have been really helpful for a lot of people. It does not lock the mouse to one screen if you have multiple monitors, but still requires that you move your mouse to the edge of the screen in order to pan the camera. It has no keyboard controls, even though it could have direly used some, such as the ablity to pan the camera with the arrow keys which would have delt with the mouse not locking issue, and a key for undo which would remove the need to click those stupid bugs (or more often, accidentally click one when you're trying to do a quick action).

Did I like it? I kept playing through the problems and beat it, so yeah I must have liked it dispite its problems. At the same time, would I recommend it? no, especially not at the normal $10 price tag. I found the missing features made it feel very unpolished and at the price point there are a lot of better games. Maybe on sale I'd recommend it, but that isn't an option.

reviewText: This game is an example of very interesting concepts and very fascinating (and disturbing) art and story.  Unfortunately, it suffers from a difficulty curve based only on how time consuming and frustrating certain levels are.  Most of the challenges rely on either counter-intuitive presentation (e.g. requiring the player to fling goo balls into an area that claims to be dangerous but isn't) or making the player guess what the physics will decide to do next.  The interface is mostly just dragging goo balls where you want them, but many of the levels require dragging specific goo balls quickly, which is often impossible to do because of the game not selecting the right one if there's any overlap.  This issue is then made worse by only certain goo balls being removable after placing them (which the player has to figure out themselves) as well as by the only way of reversing a move being to click on the little bugs that pop up for no explained or intuitive reason twice.  Not once, twice.  If you only click on one reversal bug, the game almost always reverts back to the most inconvenient possible situation.\n\nThe two biggest things I took away from this game was a deep sense of boredom and the feeling that the makers don't understand how an object's center of gravity works.  Even the constantly moving goo balls do not explain those bizarre weight mechanics work

Example: the Tower of Goo level should be a fun introduction on how to build tall towers; the solution is extremely obvious. World of Goo is an adorable, charming, and above all, inventive puzzle game developed by a couple of guys sitting in a coffee shop. It was born from a much simpler game posted on the Experimental Gameplay Project (experimentalgameplay.com) entitled Tower of Goo, in which you attached little balls of oily 'goo' to one another via stiff strings of the stuff, in an effort to create a tower that's as tall as possible without causing it to buckle and fall.

World of Goo takes this mechanic and applies it to a somewhat more varied kind of puzzle solving, introducing a myriad of different varieties of goo in addition to the basic black. (There's still a Tower of Goo mode, though, so worry not!)

Basically: buy this game. It is wonderful and you will love it.

If you're looking for a puzzle game that packs both charm and challenge, then you've come to the right place. World of Goo is almost instantly addictive for players of all skill levels, with simple controls and play mechanics that are easily grasped.

Click and drag the adorable goo balls into position to construct towers, bridges, and other structures to reach your goal. You only have a limited number of goo balls, and since some of them need to exit the level safely, you'll have to avoid hasty decisions and start planning ahead. You must carefully consider where to place the next goo ball--and (when later goo balls with different abilities are introduced) WHICH goo ball to place. It may take a few tries (and retries...and maybe even MORE retries), but you'll feel a sense of accomplishment once you've nailed the goal. Even after you've beaten the level, you can replay it again later to see if you can figure out method of achieving the goal with less moves and faster times (the OCD" goals in the menu beckon you to try this).

World of Goo is an excellent game (primarily) about building triangular-based structures by stretching Goo Balls. The goal is to use whatever utilities possible to get a certain amount of Goo Balls to a pipe. And the game introduces QUITE A LOT of goo ball variations (from balloons to flingy Goo Balls). The game's story-telling via the Sign Painter and atmosphere are little things that leave an impression. The soundtrack is also amazing and fits perfectly with the setting you're put in.\nI've only had a few problems with the game. The first being its reset system. You're only given a couple of chances to rewind time, and most times you have to do it twice since the first sends you to a time when your structure is still falling. I've found myself restarting levels when I was at the end and made one mistake often. The second is the difficulty spike during the end-game. It's possible (I did it, after all), but the first level of world 5 must've taken more than an hour and halted my craving to play for a while. Also, OCD goals (getting the maximum amount of Goo Balls possible to the end)...I'm not touching that. But if you like a really tough challenge, go for it! Finally, the game takes dominance of your screen, so don't expect to do anything else on your computer without leaving the game.\nOverall, World of Goo is great due to its consistent freshness of mechanics as well as its nerve-wracking and sometimes emotional gameplay. It's one of those indie games that isn't as recognized as it should be. Go give its creators a sale at whatever price you think is worth it ($10 isn't bad for the 6 or so hours it took to beat)!
